674786852025446400.name: mbostock

674786683666042880.text: @pzeups Even though transition A & B are on the circle elements, custom tweens can modify attributes on other elements.
674786683666042880.name: mbostock

674786574379319296.text: @pzeups Cleaner perhaps if you have transition A set the link’s y1, and transition B set the link’s y2? (Using transition.attrTween.)

674772008882667521.text: @pzeups You might not need a transition for the link; you could use a timer and refresh it continuously.
674772008882667521.name: mbostock

674771602697945088.name: mbostock

674749251230928896.text: @pzeups Have your transitions A&B expose some data (value of node’s cy), and read that from transition C. Or pull it out of the DOM.

577871073556836352.text: @tmcw I consider reactive templates a bigger abstraction, and I don’t think they support enter/exit transitions.
577871073556836352.name: mbostock

577870505060872192.text: @tmcw It’s part of it, certainly. There’s also enter.insert and enter.select, and other less common patterns.
577870505060872192.name: mbostock

577840372878946304.text: @tmcw The add’l complexity of reevaluating a big static mapping was another reason Protovis was a pain to debug.
577840372878946304.name: mbostock

577839634564055040.text: @tmcw D3 is for dynamic viz (e.g., realtime, interaction, animation). Transitions are part of that, but fast updates are also essential.
577839634564055040.name: mbostock

577838201315860481.text: @tmcw It’s not just transitions but efficiently updating display whenever anything changes, without requiring a dependency graph & diff.
577838201315860481.name: mbostock

577837560153538560.text: @tmcw Not transitions, but transformations: incremental changes to the DOM, as opposed to a static declarative mapping (as in Protovis).
577837560153538560.name: mbostock

388140322468810752.text: @wagenet I think it’s a bug in your code fixable with selection.interrupt… but if you can isolate further I can help investigate.
388140322468810752.name: mbostock

388110399477780480.text: @wagenet Actually I take that back… the first transition doesn’t tick because it’s already interrupted by the second. Anyway. Complicated.
388110399477780480.name: mbostock

388110064222871554.text: @wagenet Though I can see the deferred tick running after a subsequent transition starts, which is bad. Might need to tweak deferral logic.
388110064222871554.name: mbostock

388109600626458624.text: @wagenet That could be a latent bug with your transitions, rather than a bug in this change. You might need selection.interrupt.
388109600626458624.name: mbostock

388088703287308288.text: @wagenet Sure, you could test this: https://t.co/Rvhwd1n2iP Need to fix unit tests, also.
388088703287308288.name: mbostock

388083717241327616.text: @wagenet Another optimization we could do is defer that first tick to the end of the current timer frame by pushing it onto queueTail.
388083717241327616.name: mbostock

388082957925515264.text: @wagenet Hmm. Could drop the first frame of the transition by commenting out this line https://t.co/3aeZm2Yqcc
388082957925515264.name: mbostock

388082162584784897.text: @wagenet Also looks like the first tick of a transition.style is interleaved with the style tween initialization, causing the same problem.
388082162584784897.name: mbostock

388081396528742400.text: @wagenet The problem is transition.text runs on the first frame and invalidates the layout at the same time style values are computed.
388081396528742400.name: mbostock

388080961977872384.text: @wagenet Actually, I do see it now, on the first frame of the toggle animation. http://t.co/NQSqS6gfS6
388080961977872384.name: mbostock

388080416831574016.text: @wagenet Timeline tab, hit record, click on “toggle” button?
388080416831574016.name: mbostock

388078243393593344.text: @wagenet That fixed the problem for me. http://t.co/thvNuoriQJ
388078243393593344.name: mbostock

388068085938524160.text: @wagenet That’s with interleaved reads and writes though.
388068085938524160.name: mbostock

388067556827099136.text: @wagenet Not sure what you’re replying to. transition.tween is generic; only transition.style & styleTween deal with computed styles.
388067556827099136.name: mbostock

388066292999401472.text: @wagenet But an example might change my mind if you can demonstrate otherwise (say on http://t.co/rU7fzqGpPM)…
388066292999401472.name: mbostock

388066211604725761.text: @wagenet I don’t think it’s a big win unless you have interleaved reads and writes (which you can usually avoid)…
388066211604725761.name: mbostock

388063527686377472.text: @wagenet Because the browser typically munges set values into a standard form. And often it’s not set explicitly (e.g., inherited).
388063527686377472.name: mbostock

388057060484841472.text: @wagenet D3 doesn’t have any control flow… I mean, don’t interleave selection.style with transition.style. Do all transitions after.
388057060484841472.name: mbostock

388049085674295296.text: @wagenet You could defer the creation of any transitions until after any synchronous changes. Avoid interleaved read & write.
388049085674295296.name: mbostock

388048413990084608.text: @wagenet Also, calling getComputedStyle at the start of a transition is usually negligible compared to the transition itself.
388048413990084608.name: mbostock

388048241801318401.text: @wagenet They use getComputedStyle because they need the computed styles. Use styleTween if you want to specify your own starting value.
388048241801318401.name: mbostock

332217306539245568.text: @phaistonian :) Sorting requires multiple passes over the array, while min/max only takes a single scan. So min/max is usually faster.
332217306539245568.name: mbostock

332215360726118400.text: @phaistonian Sorting is O(n lg n); min and max is O(n).
332215360726118400.name: mbostock

332215234418864128.text: @phaistonian Math.max.apply(Math, new Array(2e5)) fails in Chrome; Max.max.apply(Math, new Array(1e6)) fails in Firefox, etc.
332215234418864128.name: mbostock

332143854465732608.text: @phaistonian You need typeof == "number", not parseInt. Also that trick only works with small arrays.
332143854465732608.name: mbostock

301064876288262144.text: @jlivni @kelsoscorner Maybe. Quantization is a (very) limited form of simplification; only coincident and adjacent vertices are removed.

301062927497183233.text: @jlivni @kelsoscorner And it was the default quantization, Q = 1e4.
301062927497183233.name: mbostock

301062763617337344.text: @jlivni @kelsoscorner Neither are simplified. It’s the quantization and delta-encoding that provide most of the savings.
